head.title: Mosley Back in Ring At Garden vs. Diaz

hedline.hl1: Mosley Back in Ring At Garden vs. Diaz

block.p: Since June 17, when Shane Mosley dethroned Oscar De La Hoya and seized the World Boxing Council welterweight title by a decision, Mosley has played some basketball, taken a Caribbean cruise and basked in the accolades. But he has not been in the ring.

A bout Nov. 4 will mark his first title defense, but it will not be a rematch with De La Hoya. Instead, Mosley will fight the junior welterweight champion, Antonio Diaz, in the Theater at Madison Square Garden.

Since June 17, when Shane Mosley dethroned Oscar De La Hoya and seized the World Boxing Council welterweight title by a decision, Mosley has played some basketball, taken a Caribbean cruise and basked in the accolades. But he has not been in the ring.

A bout Nov. 4 will mark his first title defense, but it will not be a rematch with De La Hoya. Instead, Mosley will fight the junior welterweight champion, Antonio Diaz, in the Theater at Madison Square Garden.
''I'm very anxious to get into the ring and fight,'' Mosley said yesterday on a conference call.

His promoter, Cedric Kushner, tried to schedule the rematch, but De La Hoya has put his boxing career on hold. Kushner hopes to arrange a May 5 bout against De La Hoya and is negotiating a Feb. 24 fight against Arturo Gatti.

The 28-year-old Mosley (35-0), of Ponoma, Calif., will earn $3 million for the Nov. 4 fight; Diaz (32-2), 24, from Michoacan, Mexico, will earn $360,000. Hector Camacho Jr. will fight Goyo Vargas on the undercard.
